channel.title: NPR All Things Considered
channel.description: All Things Considered hosts Ailsa Chang, Mary Louise Kelly, Ari Shapiro, Juana Summers and Scott Detrow present the program's trademark mix of news, interviews, commentaries, reviews, and offbeat features 7 days a week.

item.title: Pilgrims and clergy gather in remote Alaska village to canonize first Yup'ik saint
item.description: The Orthodox Christian tradition is strong in the tiny village of Kwethluk, Alaska. It recently welcomed clergy and pilgrims from around the world to canonize a local midwife and healer as a saint.

item.title: People say they've faced withdrawals from SSRIs. They want recognition and research
item.description: A growing number of people who take SSRIs are saying they've suffered difficult withdrawal symptoms from long-term use, including dysphoria and sexual dysfunction.

item.title: This week in science: the power of a nap, planet birth and how wildfires affect water
item.description: NPR's science podcast Short Wave shares how taking a nap can deliver a eureka moment, a new picture of a planet right after it was born, and how wildfires can affect water quality â€“ after the fires stop burning.

item.title: These drag artists know how to turn climate activism into a joyful blowout
item.description: In the Bay Area, a number of drag artists have started incorporating climate action into their performances. They say the art form is a natural vehicle for the message, given its roots in activism.

item.title: Supreme Court wraps up term with two big wins for conservatives, and Trump
item.description: The Supreme Court is allowing the Trump administration to take steps aimed at implementing its ban on birthright citizenship. It has also made it far more difficult to challenge executive orders.

item.title: SCOTUS says parents can opt kids out of lessons with LGBTQ+ characters. What's next?
item.description: NPR's Ailsa Chang talks with Stanford law professor Jeffrey Fisher about the Supreme Court ruling that parents have the right to remove their kids from class when books with LGBTQ+ themes are used.

item.title: People in Minnesota say goodbye to slain lawmaker Melissa Hortman and husband
item.description: Slain Minnesota lawmaker Melissa Hortman and her husband Mark will be buried Saturday as the public still grapples with the aftermath of the shocking political assassination a couple weeks ago.

item.title: Microsoft Windows' iconic blue screen of death is being retired
item.description: It usually happens to your computer right in the middle of something important: The dreaded Microsoft Windows blue error screen. Now Microsoft is retiring the blue screen of death for a new color.

item.title: How Steve Aoki laces EDM into every genre imaginable
item.description: EDM mega-star Steve Aoki continues to break genre boundaries with his new album HiROQUEST 3: Paragon.

item.title: Rwanda and DRC sign a U.S.-brokered peace deal, but questions remain
item.description: Rwanda and the Democratic Republic of the Congo have signed what President Trump is calling a peace deal. But the text leaves lots of questions in a complicated war in a mineral rich region of Africa.
